t: Ezekiel 27
Lamentation for Tyre
The*p word of the Lord*s came again to me, saying,
“Now, son of man, take up a lamentation for Tyre,
and say to Tyre, ‘You who are situated at the entrance of the sea, merchant of the peoples on many coastlands, thus says the Lord God:*s “O*pn Tyre, you have said, ‘I*ld am*i perfect in beauty.’
Your*ld borders are*i in the midst of the seas. Your*ld builders have perfected your beauty.
They*ld made all your*i planks of fir trees from Senir; They*ld took a cedar from Lebanon to make you a mast.
Of*ild oaks from Bashan they made your oars; The*ld company of Ashurites have inlaid your planks With*ild ivory from the coasts of Cyprus.
Fine*ld embroidered linen from Egypt was what you spread for your sail; Blue*ld and purple from the coasts of Elishah was what covered you.
“Inhabitants*ln of Sidon and Arvad were your oarsmen; Your*ld wise men, O Tyre, were in you; They*ld became your pilots.
Elders*ld of Gebal and its wise men Were*ld in you to caulk your seams; All*ld the ships of the sea And*ld their oarsmen were in you To*ld market your merchandise.
“Those*ln from Persia, Lydia, and Libya Were*ld in your army as men of war; They*ld hung shield and helmet in you; They*ld gave splendor to you.

Men*ld of Arvad with your army were*i on your walls all*i around, And*ld the men of Gammad were in your towers; They*ld hung their shields on your walls all*i around; They*ld made your beauty perfect.
“Tarshish*p was*i your merchant because of your many luxury goods. They gave you silver, iron, tin, and lead for your goods.
Javan, Tubal, and Meshech were*i your traders. They bartered human lives and vessels of bronze for your merchandise.
Those from the house of Togarmah traded for your wares with horses, steeds, and mules.
The men of Dedan were*i your traders; many isles were*i the market of your hand. They brought you ivory tusks and ebony as payment.
Syria was*i your merchant because of the abundance of goods you made. They gave you for your wares emeralds, purple, embroidery, fine linen, corals, and rubies.
Judah and the land of Israel were*i your traders. They traded for your merchandise wheat of Minnith, millet, honey, oil, and balm.
Damascus was*i your merchant because of the abundance of goods you made, because of your many luxury items, with the wine of Helbon and with white wool.
Dan and Javan paid for your wares, traversing back and forth. Wrought iron, cassia, and cane were among your merchandise.
Dedan was*i your merchant in saddlecloths for riding.
Arabia and all the princes of Kedar were*i your regular merchants. They traded with you in lambs, rams, and goats.
The merchants of Sheba and Raamah were*i your merchants. They traded for your wares the choicest spices, all kinds of precious stones, and gold.
Haran, Canneh, Eden, the merchants of Sheba, Assyria, and*i Chilmad were*i your merchants.
These were*i your merchants in choice items—in purple clothes, in embroidered garments, in chests of multicolored apparel, in sturdy woven cords, which were in your marketplace.
“The*pn ships of Tarshish were carriers of your merchandise. You*ld were filled and very glorious in the midst of the seas.
Your*ld oarsmen brought you into many waters, But*ld the east wind broke you in the midst of the seas.

“Your*ln riches, wares, and merchandise, Your*ld mariners and pilots, Your*ld caulkers and merchandisers, All*ld your men of war who are*i in you, And*ld the entire company which is*i in your midst, Will*ld fall into the midst of the seas on the day of your ruin.
The*ld common-land will shake at the sound of the cry of your pilots.
“All*ln who handle the oar, The*ld mariners, All*ld the pilots of the sea Will*ld come down from their ships and*i stand on the shore.
They*ld will make their voice heard because of you; They*ld will cry bitterly and cast dust on their heads; They*ld will roll about in ashes;
They*ld will shave themselves completely bald because of you, Gird*ld themselves with sackcloth, And*ld weep for you With*ld bitterness of heart and*i bitter wailing.
In*ld their wailing for you They*ld will take up a lamentation, And*ld lament for you: ‘What*ld city*i is*i like Tyre, Destroyed*ld in the midst of the sea?
‘When*ln your wares went out by sea, You*ld satisfied many people; You*ld enriched the kings of the earth With*ld your many luxury goods and your merchandise.
But*ld you are broken by the seas in the depths of the waters; Your*ld merchandise and the entire company will fall in your midst.
All*ld the inhabitants of the isles will be astonished at you; Their*ld kings will be greatly afraid, And*ld their*i countenance will be troubled.
The*ld merchants among the peoples will hiss at you; You*ld will become a horror, and be*i no more forever.’”’”
